Posts.Title: 4 Days till surgery - any advice?

Posts.Content: My robotic surgery will be in 4 days. I had been doing pretty well up till now in terms of keeping busy, and not letting myself get too stressed about things. I just focused on my job and my family and getting ready. But now that I've begun my time off from work, I am feeling very anxious. My main goal, of course, is for the cancer to be gone, so I think if I am fortunate enough to end up with a good pathology report, I will be in a much better state of mind. But at this point in time, my mind is just going everywhere, with worry. How will I handle perhaps months of incontinence? Will my role of being a strong and responsible parent and husband somehow be forever altered? Will the change in my sexual abilities be tolerable for me? Most importantly, what if I don't get a good surgical outcome or pathology report regarding the cancer? I am wondering if taking a mild anti-anxiety pill during the next 3 days would be okay? More generally, how should I try to spend my last 3 days "on this side" of the surgery? How did you guys cope? Or do you have any suggestions?

Posts.Title: 4 Days till surgery - any advice?

Posts.Content: My robotic surgery will be in 4 days. I had been doing pretty well up till now in terms of keeping busy, and not letting myself get too stressed about things. I just focused on my job and my family and getting ready. But now that I've begun my time off from work, I am feeling very anxious. My main goal, of course, is for the cancer to be gone, so I think if I am fortunate enough to end up with a good pathology report, I will be in a much better state of mind. But at this point in time, my mind is just going everywhere, with worry. How will I handle perhaps months of incontinence? Will my role of being a strong and responsible parent and husband somehow be forever altered? Will the change in my sexual abilities be tolerable for me? Most importantly, what if I don't get a good surgical outcome or pathology report regarding the cancer? I am wondering if taking a mild anti-anxiety pill during the next 3 days would be okay? More generally, how should I try to spend my last 3 days "on this side" of the surgery? How did you guys cope? Or do you have any suggestions?

Posts.Title: 4 Days till surgery - any advice?

Posts.Content: Three weeks ago, shortly after my surgery, I looked up the MSKCC nomogram for post-surgery. Putting in all my information, it said 5-year chance of no recurrence 88% and 10-year chance of no recurrence 79%. I am sure of this, because I did it a few times, trying different inputs just to see what would happen. Tonight I checked it again, and now it says 5-year: 73% and 10-year: 51%. Wow - I had thought I had much better odds. It was organ-confined, no positive margins. I realize this is a dynamic nomogram, but how could the odds have dropped so significantly? I noticed tonight that if I change from my Gleason of 4+3 to 3+4, the probabilities are almost the same as those I found 3 weeks ago. Another change in this nomogram is that 3 weeks ago, it showed virtually no difference in the outcome between "negative margin" and "positive margin" - which I found suspicious. This time, there is a difference in the outcomes. Do you know if this nomogram is correct? My surgeon seemed to say that my chances were very good that the cancer will not recur because of the pathology report; I was feeling pretty good, but now i am really down about it. One last thing: on page 377 of Walsh's book, it has a 71% chance of no recurrence in 10 years, and this is based on some older results. I assumed with a great, modern surgeon, that my chances would now be better than 71%, not so much worse as indicated by the nomogram. Does anyone know what is going on? My outlook has suddenly taken a bad turn.

Gleason upgraded to 4+3. 6/15 (now continent) PSA < .01; 9/15 PSA < .015; 12/15 PSA < .01; 3/16 PSA < .01
Posts.Title: Nomogram changed significantly. Very worried.

Posts.Content: There's another nomogram from Montreal: www.nomogram.org (as opposed to nomograms.org). It gave a much better outcome: 5yr = 85.8%; 10yr = 70.4%. However, it did not distinguish between 3+4 and 4+3. Even so, if you input Gleason 8 or higher, it yields 5yr = 83% and 10=65%. So, erring on the side of caution, since my Gleason is 4+3, if take the average of their Gleason 7 and their Gleason "8 or higher" - I get 76.5% and 67% for 5-yr and 10-yr, which is still much better than the MSKCC. But I don't know if Montreal's is a good nomogram or not. I am going to talk to my doctor. I had gotten okay with 79% for 10 years; but 51% for 10 years is really different - I am going to have to make another big mental adjustment or get some reason to doubt this number.

Posts.Title: Nomogram changed significantly. Very worried.

Posts.Content: Michael: i do appreciate where you're coming from, and this diagnosis served to give me a wake call for all the things you say - actually, my BMI, diet were already good. But perhaps more importantly - I have become much more aware of my need to reduce stress, and enjoy the good things I do have; and I do plan to change that significantly. I appreciate your advice. But, I just can't help but be effected by the severe change in the MSKKC nomogram - what if it had changed from 90% chance to 10% change - that really would be different; it doesn't mean I would give up, but I really would like to know this, as perhaps I would need to add an additional treatment, etc. For your info., I hardly ever check these tables - I've only looked at them twice since my diagnosis; once was right after I got home after the surgery, and once was last night - so naturally I was quite surprised to see the big change. So, for the moment, I am still interested in feeling a little better about my outlook regarding recurrence of PC. I just looked up the Han table, and it yields a much more positive outlook: 10 year: 70%; 5-year: 83%. And it does differentiate between 3+4 and 4+3; and for my PSA, I used the "10-20" range, while mine was much closer to 10. So there is nothing about my particular case that would make my outlook worse than what the Han table shows (the lymph nodes were dissected and came out clear, there were no positive margins, no extra capsular invasion, my surgeon and the path report indicates it was completely organ confined, I had one of the best surgeons in the world, and the Han tables may be a little outdated) so it makes me wonder about how the MSKCC can be giving such low numbers.

My surgeon seemed to say that my chances were very good that the cancer will not recur because of the pathology report; I was feeling pretty good, but now i am really down about it. One last thing: on page 377 of Walsh's book, it has a 71% chance of no recurrence in 10 years, and this is based on some older results. I assumed with a great, modern surgeon, that my chances would now be better than 71%, not so much worse as indicated by the nomogram. Does anyone know what is going on? My outlook has suddenly taken a bad turn.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Hi Logic, Did the biopsy report mention the staging? If it is a T2 or less (perhaps even a T3), you might have your choice between either radiation or surgery. They could all be equally curative. However, with your BPH, surgery would probably be the best route to take because it would eliminate any current (or future) urination problems you may be having. So I tend to agree with your leaning toward surgery. Chuck To answer you about the stage of the cancer, the biopsy doesn't say, but based on Dr. Walsh's book, since it was not palpable in a rectal exam, and the positive cores were confined to the left side, and since the CT scan was normal, I am thinking (and hoping) it is stage T1C. I am planning to talk to a very experienced robotic surgeon and a very experienced open surgeon, and a very experienced radiation person in the next 2 weeks. No known circulation issues; my EKG was normal; I had a little calcification in heart arteries (tested due to high cholesterol, but has become normal with statins). I have some history of fatigue issues (may have had some bout of chronic fatigue syndrome about 10 years ago, but it seemed to disappear after a year). Some tendency toward bowel issues/hemorrhoids - the fatigue and rectal things are one reason I am leaning more toward surgery - my local radiation oncologist said between 6 and 10% of people have some long-term rectal issues after radiation, and so I'm thinking that my chances might be higher.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hey Logic! Remain calm and let's figure this one out my friend! Questions: - Did you get a "Lab" copy of the PSA result or did you get the result over the phone? - Did the result come back 0.1 or <0.1? - Have you had a conversation with your MD? You mentioned only 1 decimal place. My sense is the lab ran a standard PSA assay. This exactly what happened to me at the 3 month post op mark and generated some concern. We were looking for a value of < 0.01 and the MD's office assistant told me 0.1 over the phone. Turns out it was a Standard PSA assay that was run instead of Ultrasensitive and the actual value was reported as <0.1. I always get a copy of each lab report and convert to a PDF file and store in my Digital PC folder. Recently there have been 2 separate cases of Forum Members receiving in correct PSA results (decimal point issue) over the phone from their MDs office. Additionally, this is why you want a copy of the original lab result and NOT one from e.g. your individual portal on the hospital's / clinic's website that has been transcribed and entered into your medical record. Fingers crossed! MF It was my family physician's nurse over the phone. When she said "0.1" - I asked do you mean ".01" and she said "no. 0.1" I will go there and see if I can see it myself. My surgeon said to get another test so I am going to get another one this afternoon.

Posts.Title: One year out: still good

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Ok. You haven't ruled out the radiation but when I calculate 75 minutes each way plus the minimal time to get zapped, then you're looking at a 3-hour a day crunch for 8 weeks (often 40 sessions). If you are employed, that could be problematic. Not sure how you felt it would take 5 weeks to recover from surgery. Usually, if it's robotic, you spend one night in the hospital then about a week at home with a catheter (some people actually go to work or go out in public with the catheter using a leg bag but I couldn't bring myself to do that). Normally, some leakage will follow but is mostly manageable. Some people have a longer road to full dryness. So, unless I've missed something, you're looking at 8 weeks (radiation) versus 8 days (surgery) for basically the same outcome with respect to a potential cure. Plus, as Chuck pointed out, surgery -- not radiation -- is the resolution for BPH if it rears its ugly head. And as Allen mentioned, if the cancer returns after surgery, you can have salvage radiation, as I did, as a fallback Plan "B". If the cancer returns after primary radiation, surgery is rarely an option due to the damage done to the prostate. Please let us know what you decide and why, which may be helpful to others who follow in your (our) footsteps. Best of luck to you. Jim - thanks. I didn't realize surgery recovery (back to work fulltime, I mean) is often only a couple of weeks. I thought that many people have significant incontinence for a month or more, and healing to do, that would maybe add up to 4 weeks or more. Would 4 weeks be unusually long to recovery from surgery?
Posts.Title: What questions should I ask a radiology oncologist?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 "I don't think it is feasible to get radiation for so many days and weeks if it is too far from my home. There are more experienced hospitals 75 minutes from home." By your very words, you seem to rule out radiation as a primary treatment. With that said, I would be inclined to research your surgery options. I haven't ruled out the radiation as a possible treatment. Traveling each day back and forth 75 minutes would be an inconvenience, but I wouldn't rule it out if it is a better option for me health-wise. If I get radiation 75 minutes from home, then, depending on how many weeks the radiation lasts, it may not be any more inconvenient for me (thinking of how many weeks I will be out of work) than if it takes me 5 weeks or more to recover from the surgery. My own urologist seemed to prefer radiation but also added that he had some concern that with a larger than average size prostate, the radiation may make it swell more and possibly cause some constriction. One hope I'd have, regardless of the treatment, is to minimize future annoyances like catheters, cystascoping, needing to shrink the prostate, constriction problems, etc. I'm still pretty confused about which treatment - but I am hopeful that my visit to John's Hopkins "Multidisciplinary Consultation" will help a great deal.

Posts.Title: Should I have a bone scan?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH My urologist at home, who diagnosed my PC, told me I had low risk Gleason 6, which fortunately was confirmed by the post-op pathology. He also sent me in for the abdominal CT scan and nuclear bone scan. He told me in ADVANCE that both scans would be negative. But many doctors like to do this automatically, as the others have noted, just to establish baseline readings. They inject the radioactive dye in a vein and then you have to wait 2 hours for the dye to completely circulate through your body. The test, itself, takes about 20 minutes and is completely painless. No reason to NOT take it because it is likely to give additional peace of mind that there are no bone mets, etc. I decided I better have it. It will take place on Wednesday due to a clerical error. Thanks for your thoughts. This website has been very helpful to me.

Posts.Title: I have finally decided on the treatment. Question about travel after surgery.

Posts.Content: I want to thank everyone who participates in this forum. It has been of great help to me since I was diagnosed on Dec. 17. I have decided to go with robotic surgery and I am comfortable with the decision. It will be done at Johns Hopkins. Since I live far from John Hopkins, the tentative plan is to spend two extra days in a hotel near the hospital after the surgery to make sure I can travel - the surgeon suggested this in case of any complications. I am wondering, for any of you who had surgery far from home, do you have any suggestions regarding flying (2 hour flight) or driving (15 hours - 2 days). I am a bit nervous about the travel because I understand that it is recommended to walk frequently during the days following surgery, and also something about not sitting still in a cramped seat for very long. If I fly, I'd probably spend extra and fly 1st class for the extra leg room. The plane and getting through a huge airport sounds terrible - but a 2 day car trip seems even worse. Thanks.

Posts.Content: I had my surgery 16 days ago, and the catheter removed 7 days ago. I am just wondering, for each of the issues I am now having (which are listed below): (a) is this a normal problem, to be expected at this point in my recovery?, and (b) if it is normal, when might it go away? Here are the issues: 1. each night, I wake up about 3 or 4 times during the night with a strong urge to urinate and have to get out of bed and run to the bathroom in order to urinate; during the day, I have to urinate about every hour or hour and a half, and have to do so very soon after drinking a glass of water (note: I am not drinking anything later than 7pm) 2. whenever I urinate, it burns a little, and it is even a little painful sometimes, especially near the end of the penis 3. when I urinate, if I try to stop and re-start the stream (this Kegel exercise was advised to me by my doctor), more often than not I am unsuccessful in "shutting off the valve" (it just keeps on flowing) 4. there is general discomfort, and sometimes an ache, at various places in the groin area, including my backside 5. my intestines are not working normally - bowel movements are less well-formed than normal; not sure if I should increase fiber or take a bulking agent (this is contrary to taking a laxative or a stool softener, but with loose stools already, I have stopped taking stool softener) 6. very little stamina; hoping I can return to work in the coming weeks 7. not sleeping soundly enough - even though I am feeling physically tired, I am not sleeping as many hours as I'd like to. Thanks.

Posts.Title: Two weeks after surgery - are these complaints normal at this stage?

Posts.Content: Today makes 4 weeks post-surgery and 2.5 weeks post-catheter removal. Each week is better. Here's an update on all of the complaints I listed 2 weeks ago: I am now waking up only 1 or twice per night. Urgency during the day is getting better each week. The burning during urination is barely noticeable. Urgency during the day has decreased by around 50%. One stool softener per day has gotten things better in that area. General aching is down a great deal. Sleeping has improved. Energy slowly increasing. In addition, incontinence is gradually getting better: went from wearing the depends briefs to tena moderate guards; leaking down from 0.5oz or more per day to 0.2oz or 0.3oz per day. Can get by with just two guards per day. Ordered the lightest version - almost no leaking while I sleep. Patience is the key!! Just do all the recommended exercises and avoidances and be patient.

Posts.Content: I am wondering: what is the longest one should wait between the time of the biopsy and having surgery? I had my biopsy on Dec. 5; received the cancer diagnosis on Dec. 17. After doing all my research and consulting, I made my decision yesterday, Jan. 20, on having robotic surgery and on who would do the surgery. My understanding was that the surgeon had approximately a 4 week wait for surgery - so I expected to have the surgery sometime around Feb. 15 or Feb. 20. But it turns out that his earliest available date is March 9. Bottom line: the time between my biopsy and the surgery will be a little over 13 weeks (Dec. 5 till Mar. 9). It seems 8 weeks is about normal for those in this forum. Should I consider finding another surgeon at this point - the surgeon I choose is a top surgeon and I am happy with my choice, but don't want to risk the cancer getting worse because of waiting too long to have it treated. My Gleason is 3+4. Also, do you happen to know the likelihood of one of his patients cancelling their appointment before then (if there's a cancellation, they'll let me know)? My only alternative is to choose my 2nd choice for a surgeon, which would likely save me about 2 weeks. Did any of you have an intermediate risk case like mine, and take 3 months for the surgery after biopsy? Thanks

Posts.Content: Just diagnosed a few days ago. I have to decide between surgery and external radiation. I have Gleason 3+4 in two cores (out of twelve). PSA has been steadily climbing last 3 years. PSA density is around 0.2. Two years ago I had a negative biopsy, so we waited, but this one was positive. I want to choose the treatment that will be more likely to give me no recurrence and so that I have a good quality of life for years to come. I would greatly appreciate hearing from any of you that have had either treatment and how it turned out (and if you feel it was the right choice of treatment). Or any advice.
Posts.Title: Must decide between surgery and radiation

Posts.Content: Yes - I am 63 and otherwise am healthy - not overweight; slightly high blood pressure (140/83). No prostate cancer in family. Great longevity in my family.

I want to choose the treatment that will be more likely to give me no recurrence and so that I have a good quality of life for years to come. I would greatly appreciate hearing from any of you that have had either treatment and how it turned out (and if you feel it was the right choice of treatment). Or any advice.
Posts.Title: Must decide between surgery and radiation

Posts.Content: Dear all: Thanks so much for your replies. To respond to Chuck's question. My stage is T1C. My PSA is 11.9. Both positive cores 3+4 are in the transition area. Negative on DRE. Two years ago, I had a negative biopsy, and my PSA was 7 at that time. My psa density is now 0.2, back two years ago, it was 0.13. My two positive cores say 56% and 41% - not sure if that means the percentage of "3" cells in each of those cores.

Posts.Title: At Johns Hopkins Tomorrow

Posts.Content: I had my surgery at JH 3 weeks ago. I can tell you that Dr. Allaf is one of the best, and is very honest. Ask all the questions you'd like. Note also that biopsies give only a sample, and aren't always the same as what is given in the final pathology report which can only be known with the surgery option. The final decision on treatment is a very personal matter. For your questions, I would focus on the probability of a cure with each treatment, and ask about long-term side effects and their probabilities with each treatment. Best of luck.

Posts.Content: I think I've decided on going to Johns Hopkins for their 1-day consultation. A team studies your case and then give you some recommendations for treatment. I am hoping that will give me some more piece of mind in regards to choosing the right treatment.
Posts.Title: Do you recommend one of these famous cancer centers for general consultation?

Posts.Content: I had my surgery last week, and had what the doc called a very good path report. But now that I have a copy of the actual report, I have a question. First of all, here are the good things that the report says: "organ-confined throughout (PT2 grade)" "summary margins: negative" "no seminal vescicle invasion" "all 7 pelvic lymph nodes negative for invasion" "no regional lymph node invasion" All of that, as told to me by the doc, is the best possible outcome. But the one thing that I'm unclear about is that it says "lymphatic (small vessel) invasion: present" I think these small vessels are in the prostate, and if so, they should now be removed, but I wish I had some re-assurance that there is no way the cancer could have already metasthesized. Do any of you have any experience of having this as part of your pathology report? Thanks

Posts.Content: I would go ahead with the .psa test. But if you are worried in the interim, you might want to get a second opinion from another urologist. An enlarged prostate is not so unusual - it is much different than feeling a "nodule." I do suggest you have the .psa for peace of mind, but unless there is a suspicious lump, it seems very doubtful there is anything serious.

Posts.Title: 41 years old PSA of 0.9 and Urologist said wants to have another PSA done in 4 months

Posts.Content: Today makes 7 weeks since my RALP. At 2 weeks out, I posted a thread with a list of several post-operative problems I was having; then at 4 weeks out, I gave an update. Now that I am 7 weeks out, I thought it might be helpful to those who are nearer to their surgery date than me, to compare the symptoms for "2 weeks post-op" vs. "4 weeks post-op" vs. "7 weeks post-op." I was really frustrated at 2 weeks, so I do this just to give one more example of what many others have said on this site: "be patient: it does get better." And also to support what others told me (that helped me): that improvements are probably not going to be noticeable from one day to the next, but they likely will be noticed as the weeks go by. Comparison: 2 weeks vs. 4 weeks vs. 7 weeks: Complaint #1: leakage/incontinence 2 weeks out: wearing depends briefs; leaking around 0.5 oz. per day; 0.2oz during the night while sleeping 4 weeks out: wearing medium tena guards; leaking 0.2 - 0.3 oz. per day; 0.1oz or less during the night 7 weeks out: wearing light tena guards: leaking 0.1 oz per day; 0 during the night Complaint #2: waking during the night with urge to urinate: 2 weeks out: 3 or 4 times per night, having to run to the bathroom 4 weeks out: 1 or 2 times per night, still rushing to bathroom 7 weeks out: still 1 or 2 times per night, but urgency is not as strong Complaint #3: burning during urination 2 weeks out: when urinating, it burns a little, and it is even a little painful sometimes, especially near the end of the penis 4 weeks out: very slight burning 7 weeks out: no burning Complaint #4: during urination, difficulty in stopping and-restarting (Kegel exercise) 2 weeks out: failed to stop the flow more than 50% of the attempts 4 weeks out: successful 100% of the time 7 weeks out: successful 100% of the time Complaint #5: pain/discomfort in general area 2 weeks out: general discomfort, and sometimes an ache, at various places in the groin area, including my backside 4 weeks out: discomfort has decreased by maybe 50% 7 weeks out: no pain or discomfort - sometimes the glue at incision spots are a little itchy or burn just a little Complaint #6: urgency to urinate during the day 2 weeks out: every time I had to urinate, the urge was very strong, and I was going every hour or so 4 weeks out: great decrease in urgency; typically 1.5 to 2 hours between having to go 7 weeks out: only mild feeling of urgency; typically go every 2-3 hours Complaint #7: stomach problems 2 weeks out: digestive system really messed up - very irregular, have to eat extremely bland diet 4 weeks out: almost normal, still eating rather plain diet 7 weeks out: all is well; can eat a reasonably varied diet now Complain #8: low energy 2 weeks out: very little stamina; not convinced I'll be able to return to work in 3 more weeks 4 weeks out: energy level maybe 50% of what I'd like it to be; still haven't driven my car 7 weeks out: energy level maybe 75%-80% of what I'd like it to be; can go to work for 6 hours a day with little difficulty; driving, walking

Posts.Content: I am glad this may helpful to others. This site has been a great resource and comfort to me, and I want to contribute to help other who are newer to this situation. Regarding incontinence, there are still some days that are worse than others - where I seem to have way too many "squirts." I have the idea that this happens more when I have less energy - it especially happens more in the evening after a reasonably busy day. I also think I have slackened off somewhat on regularly doing Kegels, so I am determined to do them much more regularly again. I am hoping that eventually I can stop wearing the pads altogether. But it is true, as I look back over the weeks, that things are much better than they were 3 or 4 weeks ago.
